descript.abstract: Mining Centers, 1996 is a point theme representing major Mining centers worldwide. Attribute information includes the name of the mining center, the size and ecological impact of the mining activity and the type of mining resource.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf:
The present-day extractive industry is actually a complex of mineral extraction and ore dressing industries. It includes fuel production and extraction of ore, chemical raw materials, and nonmetallic minerals including diamonds, graphite, feldspar, fluorspar, asbestos, mica, dolomite, quartzite, and building materials. Extractive industry is essential for supplying regions and nations with the raw materials and energy necessary for economic development. Its impact is reflected in the distribution patterns of the world economy.
The spatial distribution and production structure of extractive industry are determined by a great number of factors. These factors include geology and geography of mineral beds, their reserves, qualities, accessibility, and natural and climatic conditions. Social and economic conditions are also important. They include internal and external market demands for raw materials, the equipment and technology of mining and processing, infrastructure, and the labor force.
Serious environmental impacts result from many mining activities.

procstep.procdesc:
Mining centers were selected for the atlas according to the volume of their output and the relative severity of their environmental impact. Because mining output ranges from kilograms (e.g., gold) to millions of tons (e.g., coal), the amounts of ore extracted were used in order to compare the environmental impact of mining. The minerals and extraction technologies being used were the basis for the determination of environmental impact of the activity. Extraction of nonmetallic minerals stands out in its harmful impact on the environment. However, some centers of nonmetallic mining are not included in the atlas because of lack of fundamental information.
